image.altText: An old newspaper article on the death of Vincenzo D'Agostino, the leader of The Black Hand.

items.synopsis: For years, Vincenzo D'Agostino terrorised and extorted Italian migrants across Far North Queensland as leader of the mafia group the Black Hand. His rule was a defining period for the regional Italian community, but one fact remains unsolved — who turned the tables, and murdered him?

title.children: Mafia, murder and mystery — how one man's rule of terror was brought undone in Far North Queensland

image.altText: A man looks to the left of frame pensively. He wears an army uniform and stands by what appears to be a camp

items.synopsis: Wagner's mutiny may be over, but from secret locations inside Russia and Ukraine, guerilla groups are dodging Moscow's crackdown on dissidents to sabotage Putin's plans and help Ukraine win the war.

title.children: Putin may have dealt with the Wagner threat, but another group of militants are threatening to bring him down

image.altText: Vladimir Putin speaking in black suit and tie flanked by Russian flag.

items.synopsis: Russia's President Vladimir Putin has used a late night address to promise Wagner troops can go to Belarus, join Russia, or be with their families.

title.children: Putin blames 'enemies' for rebellion attempt as Wagner Group denies trying to overthrow Russian government

image.altText: Wagner mercenary fighters on top of a tank, with a Wagner flag.

items.synopsis: A former Russian diplomat who defected from his post at the United Nations in 2022 says Vladimir Putin's inner circle is shrinking and most people inside the Kremlin do not support the war against Ukraine.

title.children: 'Majority of people in the Kremlin unhappy about this war', Russia defector reveals

image.altText: Man in cowboy hat with sunset in background

items.synopsis: Stuart Mackenzie was unfamiliar with cryptocurrency before being approached to build a miner on his remote property in outback Queensland but he has embraced the idea.

title.children: This Queensland sheep farmer is not your average 'crypto bro'

image.altText: Sign at Cairns School of Distance Education surrounded by trees

items.synopsis: Teachers at Queensland's second largest state school have been told to use their "on-balance judgement" and still give a grade to students who don't undertake formal assessment, a leaked email has revealed.

title.children: 'Ghost students' could pass under distance education school's changed grading policy, teacher says

image.altText: The PwC logo is shown on an office building.

items.synopsis: In a sublime combination of breathtaking arrogance and dazzling ineptitude, the Australian arm of global accounting giant PwC has managed to turn a possible crime into a national crisis and then allowed it to evolve into a catastrophe, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: PwC hacks off an arm, but still won't come clean

image.altText: Ashleigh Gardner with her hands raised on a cricket field with two other players visible.

items.synopsis: Ashleigh Gardner produces the second-best bowling match figures by a woman in history to spin her side to an 89-run Ashes Test victory over England at Trent Bridge.

title.children: Ash Gardner produces history to lead Australian women to Ashes Test triumph

image.altText: A man in a suit

items.synopsis: Victoria Police has been accused of racial profiling, with newly released data revealing people of African or Middle Eastern appearance received a disproportionate number of COVID-19 fines in the first year of the pandemic.

title.children: Victoria Police deny racial profiling accusations as data shows disparity in COVID fines

image.altText: Jody Ekert opens PO Box 727.

items.synopsis: Vernon Marshall convinced a postmaster in the 1970s to let him open a PO Box for the queer community to write to him. Today, the concept returns to Tamworth.

title.children: How Jody and PO Box 727 will carry on the legacy of a fearless gay pioneer

image.altText: A group of smiling Australian cricketers raise their hands for a high five to congratulate a bowler after she takes a wicket.

items.synopsis: The win at Trent Bridge which puts Australia halfway to retaining the Women's Ashes, comes despite two of its stars, spinner Ashleigh Gardner and skipper Alyssa Healy, playing all five days with finger injuries.

title.children: Gardner, Healy overcome fickle fingers to spur Australia to Women's Ashes Test win

image.altText: An office worker talks on his phone as he looks the stock board at the Australian Securities Exchange

items.synopsis: The Australian share market is likely to recover slightly from its three-month low as technology stocks were the biggest drags on Wall Street, while oil prices rose slightly after Russia's aborted weekend mutiny.

title.children: ASX to rise above three-month low, Wall Street slips after aborted Russian mutiny

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Prudential and Regulation Authority ( APRA ) will force Medibank Private to hold an extra $250 million in capital, as punishment for last year's data breach — which resulted in the records of 9.7 million customers being stolen and released on the dark web. Essentially, that's money or assets that Medibank needs to set aside, which can't be used for other purposes. The financial regulator said this measure will take effect from July 1, and will remain in place "until an agreed remediation program of work is completed by Medibank to APRA's satisfaction". APRA also said it will conduct a "targeted technology review" of the health insurer, focusing on its governance and risk culture. “In taking this action, APRA seeks to ensure that Medibank expedites its remediation program,” said APRA member Suzanne Smith. "APRA expects Medibank to ensure there is appropriate accountability and consequence management, including impacts to executive remuneration where appropriate. Ms Smith added that her organisation continues to see "poor cyber security practices and inadequate oversight from boards and management".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: APRA penalises Medibank for last year's hacking scandal

children.content: The Australian Prudential and Regulation Authority (
APRA
) will force
Medibank Private
to hold an extra
$250 million
in capital, as punishment for last year's data breach — which resulted in the records of
9.7 million customers
being stolen and released on the dark web.
Essentially, that's money or assets that Medibank needs to set aside, which can't be used for other purposes.
The financial regulator said this measure will take effect from July 1, and will remain in place "until an agreed remediation program of work is completed by Medibank to APRA's satisfaction".
APRA also said it will conduct a "targeted technology review" of the health insurer, focusing on its governance and risk culture.
“In taking this action, APRA seeks to ensure that Medibank expedites its remediation program,” said APRA member Suzanne Smith.
"APRA expects Medibank to ensure there is appropriate accountability and consequence management, including impacts to executive remuneration where appropriate.
Ms Smith added that her organisation continues to see "poor cyber security practices and inadequate oversight from boards and management".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! I'll be here to guide you through today's market and economic news. The local share market is expected to begin its day marginally higher, as it attempts to recover from a four-day losing streak. Wall Street fell, while and oil prices rose slightly as investors digested the aborted Russian mutiny over the weekend. Global stock markets are also being weighed down by lingering concerns over the path of the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy and the pace of its upcoming interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones was flat, while the S & P 500 and Nasdaq Composite fell by 0.5% and 1.2% respectively. Geopolitical turmoil dampened risk appetites in the wake of an aborted mutiny in Russia, which appeared to reveal cracks in Russian President Vladimir Putin's grip on power. "I don't think investors in equities or fixed income are that concerned about (Russia), unless it balloons into something more," said Paul Nolte, senior wealth adviser and market strategist at Murphy & Silvest. The mutiny attempt's "lifespan has ended and there's nothing else to see and do here," he added. Financial markets are now betting there's a 77% chance of the US central bank lifting its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points in July, according to CME's FedWatch tool. On oil markets, Brent crude futures rose 0.5% to $US74.18 a barrel.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX to rise, depite Wall Street losses

children.content: Good morning! I'll be here to guide you through today's market and economic news.
The local share market is expected to begin its day marginally higher, as it attempts to recover from a four-day losing streak.
Wall Street fell, while and oil prices rose slightly as investors digested the aborted Russian mutiny over the weekend.
Global stock markets are also being weighed down by lingering concerns over the path of the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy and the pace of its upcoming interest rate hikes.
The Dow Jones was flat, while the S
P 500 and Nasdaq Composite fell by 0.5% and 1.2% respectively.
Geopolitical turmoil dampened risk appetites in the wake of an aborted mutiny in Russia, which appeared to reveal cracks in Russian President Vladimir Putin's grip on power.
"I don't think investors in equities or fixed income are that concerned about (Russia), unless it balloons into something more," said Paul Nolte, senior wealth adviser and market strategist at Murphy
Silvest.
The mutiny attempt's "lifespan has ended and there's nothing else to see and do here," he added.
Financial markets are now betting there's a 77% chance of the US central bank lifting its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points in July, according to CME's FedWatch tool.
On oil markets, Brent crude futures rose 0.5% to $US74.18 a barrel.

image.altText: A man in a high-vis shirt standing inside a warehouse and smiling.

items.synopsis: In some communities where the federal government's changes to the remote work-for-the-dole program are being trialled, residents like Chris Farrell are reporting success.

title.children: 'Keep it going': Indigenous communities appeal for better work-for-the-dole conditions to continue

image.altText: One basketballer shoots and another attempts to spoil.

items.synopsis: Seventeen years after she was part of a golden moment with the Opals, basketballer and four-time Olympian Laura Hodges has stepped back onto the court.

title.children: This former Opal couldn't resist the temptation of another shot at glory

image.altText: A submersible under sea with air bubbles coming out from the top.

items.synopsis: An international investigation into the cause of the undersea implosion of a tourist submersible that killed all five people on board is underway. So, what happens next?

title.children: What happens next with the wreckage of OceanGate's submersible Titan?

image.altText: A police car and tape

items.synopsis: Police received a report that a number of people were in the vicinity of the injured teenager, and they appeared to be armed with a knife.

title.children: Teenage boy, 14, dies after being found injured on road in Melbourne's north-west

image.altText: A ceramic coffee mug sits on a desk near a laptop and a desk lamp in a dark room.

items.synopsis: Given freedom-of-speech concerns, technical challenges and the difficulty of taking on big tech, it makes sense that the government is keen for Silicon Valley to lead the way in developing its own code of conduct.

title.children: Australia vs the internet: What can the government do to fight online misinformation?

image.altText: A football on the ground during Hawthorn Hawks' training session at Waverley Park in 2008.

items.synopsis: An internationally-renowned advocate on the dangers of traumatic brain injuries has backed the AFL's crackdown on head-high bumps and dangerous tackles, and is calling for urgent changes to the way footballers train and play.

title.children: AFL must urgently change how the game is trained and played, concussion expert says

image.altText: A woman looks out at a path

items.synopsis: As police increase patrols in areas where assaults have occurred, some women are opting to carry personal alarms or exercise without headphones.

title.children: Women avoid one of Alice Springs' most popular walking trails in wake of indecent assaults

image.altText: Nvidia logo displayed on a mobile phone screen with a circuit board in the background.

items.synopsis: The company behind much of the technology fuelling artificial intelligence has seen its shares surge almost 200 per cent this year as part of a wider AI boom, but are those sky-high valuations justified?

title.children: This company's AI potential just 'blew everything out of the park', but can it live up to its surging share value?

image.altText: Jennifer Howard holding a small dog

items.synopsis: An Adelaide not-for-profit organisation that helps struggling pet owners says the housing crisis has pushed demand for its services to record levels, forcing it to turn some people away.

title.children: Animal shelters inundated as SA pet owners seeking rentals make 'heartbreaking' choices

image.altText: A woman wearing a hair net and apron stands on a factory production line with co-workers assembling speakers

items.synopsis: Australia is relying on its largest trading partner to bounce back, but China's youth unemployment figures and low consumer confidence are slowing down much-needed growth, suggesting a full recovery will take some time.

title.children: China's post-COVID economic recovery appears to be sputtering. Here's why

image.altText: A wooden sign marks the entrance of the new Bundaberg Brewed Drinks premises

items.synopsis: The men were taken to Bundaberg Hospital, where three are in a stable condition and one is in a serious condition.

title.children: Four men suffer facial burns in gas explosion at Bundaberg brewing company

image.altText: Black and white photo of Nel Law smiling slightly with closed mouth, against plain background, wearing woolen turtleneck jumper.

items.synopsis: The rules prevented women from going to Antarctica in the 1960s, but Nel Law defied them. Now author Rachael Mead wants more people to learn about Nel's legacy.

title.children: In the 60s, Nel Law was a stowaway on a ship to Antarctica. What she saw there blew her mind

image.altText: A close up photo of what appears to be orange citrus fruit with blue-grey mould on it

items.synopsis: Usually, mould spores are invisible — but give them a niche to exploit and you'll get all kinds of colours on the things in your home, writes Michael Taylor.

title.children: Black, blue, yellow or pink: What do the different colours of mould in my house mean?

image.altText: young man holds rugby league ball on field

items.synopsis: A 16-year-old "passionate" rugby league player described as having a "big future" in the sport has died after being hit by a car.

title.children: Rugby league young gun remembered after fatal collision

image.altText: Gwenda Darling, a woman with pink hair, stands in a garden wearing a black scarf and striped jumper.

items.synopsis: Gwenda struggled with her dementia diagnosis at first, but now she's looking forward to the future and "living her best life".

title.children: Gwenda was told she had five years to live after a dementia diagnosis. That was 11 years ago

image.altText: two female students carrying handbags walk through a university campus. they are facing away from the camera

items.synopsis: Queensland TAFE and universities have been put on notice after the state's auditor-general warned their financial futures are at risk.

title.children: Cost-of-living crisis fuelling dwindling uni enrolments, TAFE's sustainability 'at risk', Queensland auditor-general says

image.altText: A person lights a candle outside a nightclub, they are surrounded by floral tributes.

items.synopsis: The Colorado nightclub shooter is sentenced to life in prison after pleading guilty to the "intentional" death of five victims.

title.children: Colorado LGBTQ+ nightclub shooter sentenced to life in prison
